Requests for permission for commercial publication or other use should be emailed to the project team.

div1.p:
Your Eminence,
I received the two letters that Your Imperial Highness did me the honor of addressing to me,on the dates of January 29th and the 19th of this month, on the subject of the armed visit operated on the west coast of Africa by the english warship l'alecto on the ship the Phoenix, affected to an operation of recruitment of blacks for our colonies. At the time of the first of these letters
div1.ab: Your Imperial Highness the Prince charged of the Department of évée and the Colonies.
div1.p: one was arriving, I was coming from receiving as well one from Mr. Minister of the Navy on the same subject, Mr. Admiral Hamelin, in announcing to me the ulterior commmunication of the details that were sent to him on this affair, was asking me to set it formerly, so that he could make a judgment on the conduct of the delegate and on the captain of the Phoenix, on the stretch of coast under the jurisdiction of the Republic of Liberia. I supposed that my response to Mr. Minister of the Navy would be followed by the communication that he had forseen for me; I waited for it in order to be capable of responding as well to the letter from your Imperial Highness, I have not however received anything yet. I hasten,

consequently, to transmit to your Imperial highness a copy of what I had written to Mr. Admiral Hamelin on the subject of the question of Liberia, it is how she will see it, that by the information received, either from the Minister of Algeria and the Colonies, or from that of the Navy that my Department could be fixed itself on the expanse vielle of these limits. As for the act of visit effected by the Alecto I am going to examine the circumstances and I will have care as soon as the result of the examination has been submitted to me, instruct your Imperial Highness of the developments pf which this affair will appear susceptible.
I have the honnor to be with a respectful consideration, Your Eminence,
